docs.abstract: The arrest of a woman with a malware-laced device revealed the challenge of protecting a president who prefers a resort over Camp David.
docs.snippet: The arrest of a woman with a malware-laced device revealed the challenge of protecting a president who prefers a resort over Camp David.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The arrest of a Chinese woman who carried a malware-laced device into Mar-a-Lago, President Trump’s Florida resort, has exposed porous security at the private club and escalating tensions between Secret Service agents and the resort’s staff members, who vet guest lists and allow people onto the sprawling grounds.

headline.main: Malware Arrest Exposes Security Gaps at Trump’s Mar-a-Lago Club
headline.print_headline: Malware Arrest Bares a Vulnerable Mar-a-Lago

byline.original: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Katie Rogers and Alexandra Stevenson

docs.abstract: The president had blamed Ms. Nielsen for the rise in migrants who illegally entered the United States even though she supported his hard-line immigration policies.
docs.snippet: The president had blamed Ms. Nielsen for the rise in migrants who illegally entered the United States even though she supported his hard-line immigration policies.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Kirstjen Nielsen, the homeland security secretary, resigned on Sunday after meeting with President Trump, ending a tumultuous tenure in charge of the border security agency that had made her the target of the president’s criticism.

headline.main: Kirstjen Nielsen Resigns as Trump’s Homeland Security Secretary
headline.print_headline: Secretary Is Out as Border Influx Sours President

byline.original: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Maggie Haberman, Michael D. Shear and Eric Schmitt

docs.abstract: The appointment of Thomas D. Homan to oversee border policy is likely to undercut the homeland security secretary’s traditional role as the top official responsible for border security.
docs.snippet: The appointment of Thomas D. Homan to oversee border policy is likely to undercut the homeland security secretary’s traditional role as the top official responsible for border security.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday again shook up his immigration team, appointing a hard-liner to coordinate border policy from the White House and sending a message that he is redoubling his efforts to prevent migrants from entering the United States.

headline.main: Trump Appoints a Loyalist as ‘Border Czar’ in Latest Immigration Reshuffle
headline.print_headline: President Picks Loyalist, A Former Leader of ICE, To Be His ‘Border Czar’

byline.original: By Michael D. Shear and Zolan Kanno-Youngs

docs.abstract: Mr. Trump’s statements come after weeks of public backlash and allegations over how the Border Patrol cares for detained migrants.
docs.snippet: Mr. Trump’s statements come after weeks of public backlash and allegations over how the Border Patrol cares for detained migrants.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump said on Wednesday that migrants were “living far better” in Border Patrol detention centers than in their home countries, one day after his own administration reported that children in some facilities were denied hot meals or showers, and that cells were so crowded that migrants begged to be freed.

headline.main: Trump Says Migrants Are ‘Living Far Better’ in Overcrowded Border Facilities
headline.print_headline: It’s a ‘Far Better’ Life in Detention, Trump Says

docs.abstract: The complaints come after the Trump administration moved to decertify the union.
docs.snippet: The complaints come after the Trump administration moved to decertify the union.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The union representing the nation’s immigration judges filed two labor complaints against the Justice Department on Friday, escalating a fight between the Trump administration and those who play a central role in the White House’s attempt to limit immigration to the United States.

headline.main: Immigration Judges’ Union Lodges Labor Complaints Against Trump Administration
headline.print_headline: Union for Immigration Judges Lodges Complaints Against the Justice Department

docs.abstract: The court has ruled that racial gerrymanders can violate the Constitution, but it has struggled with voting maps warped by politics.
docs.snippet: The court has ruled that racial gerrymanders can violate the Constitution, but it has struggled with voting maps warped by politics.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Thursday ruled that federal courts are powerless to hear challenges to partisan gerrymandering, the practice in which the party that controls the state legislature draws voting maps to help elect its candidates.

headline.main: Supreme Court Bars Challenges to Partisan Gerrymandering

docs.abstract: The lively argument included discussions of whiskey punch and the novels of Agatha Christie.
docs.snippet: The lively argument included discussions of whiskey punch and the novels of Agatha Christie.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Wednesday considered the reach of the Clean Water Act, debating how it applies to pollutants that reach the sea and other protected waters indirectly, through groundwater.

headline.main: Supreme Court Weighs Limits on Water Pollution Law
headline.print_headline: Supreme Court Weighs Limits on Water Pollution Law

docs.abstract: Challengers argued that the cross in suburban Maryland sent a message of government favoritism toward Christianity.
docs.snippet: Challengers argued that the cross in suburban Maryland sent a message of government favoritism toward Christianity.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Thursday that a 40-foot cross honoring soldiers who died in World War I could remain on state property in suburban Maryland. The cross, the court said, did not violate the First Amendment’s ban on government establishment of religion.

headline.main: Supreme Court Allows 40-Foot Peace Cross on State Property
headline.print_headline: Justices Allow 40-Foot Cross Built in 1925 to Remain on State Property

docs.abstract: A confusing 1972 decision allowed convictions by split verdicts in state courts, though not federal ones. The justices struggled with whether to overrule it.
docs.snippet: A confusing 1972 decision allowed convictions by split verdicts in state courts, though not federal ones. The justices struggled with whether to overrule it.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost every part of the Bill of Rights applies to both the federal government and to the states, but the Supreme Court on Monday wrestled with whether to tolerate a rare exception for non-unanimous jury verdicts in criminal cases. Such verdicts are forbidden in federal trials under the Sixth Amendment but permitted in ones held in state court.

headline.main: Supreme Court Weighs Ending Non-Unanimous Jury Verdicts in Criminal Cases
headline.print_headline: A Debate to End Criminal Convictions by Split Verdicts

docs.abstract: The new case, about a subpoena from a House committee, follows one arising from a grand jury subpoena from Manhattan prosecutors.
docs.snippet: The new case, about a subpoena from a House committee, follows one arising from a grand jury subpoena from Manhattan prosecutors.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump asked the Supreme Court on Friday to shield his financial records from disclosure to investigators for the second time in two days. His latest request was an emergency application that asked the court to temporarily block the release of records held by his accounting firm to a House committee while the justices consider whether to hear his appeal.

headline.main: Trump Again Asks Supreme Court to Block Release of His Financial Records
headline.print_headline: Trump Again Asks Top Court to Block Release of His Financial Records
